Data in fieldbook: Original names written by Saint-Hilaire and number of collection
column3: Traditional uses

Names of family: Gomphrena arborescens L.f. ( =G. officinalis Mart.) ,b ANACARDIACEAE
column3: Bitter root, used for the throat; anti-scorbutic
Edible fruits
Fresh leaves have a varnish odour; it is stated that the body swells when sleeping under the shade of the tree
Recent studies: Presence of volatile oil (El-Massry et al., 2009; Bendaoud et al., 2010; Sallam et al., 2011)

Names of family: Annona squamosa L., A.reticulata L., A. sylvatica A. St.-Hil., A. glabra L. (=A. palustris L.), A. cornifolia A. St.-Hil.e
column3: The fruits are eaten, they are the size of a small apple (pomme de Reinette). There are several species

Names of family: Duguetia furfuracea(A. St.-Hil.) Saff. (=Annona furfuracea A. St.-Hil.)d.f.b
column3: Edible fruits
Light wood
Not described
Edible fruits
Roots used in the cerrado as a purgative, they are bitter and a little nauseating

Names of family: Himatanthus lancifolius (Müll. Arg.) Woodson Mandevilla velame Pichon (=Macrosiphonia velame (A. St.-Hil.) Müll.
Data in fieldbook: Para tudo [D-42] Cha de General/Apocinaceae/ Echites vellame [C1-380; C1- 611(9)], Vellame [B1-202]
column3: Bitter bark, used for fevers Decoction of leaves to treat indigestion and stomach troubles

Names of family: AQUIFOLIACEAE Ilex paraguariensis A. St.-Hil. c.d.g.b.
Data in fieldbook: Erva de Mate ou Congonha/Ilex paraguariensis [D-384ter]
column3: Not described

Names of family: ARISTOLOCHIACEAE Aristolochia cymbifera Mart. & Zucc.e.c.d,b ASTERACEAE
column3: Leaves used in decoction to treat erysipelas
Recent studies: Antimicrobial (Machado et al., 2005; Alviano et al., 2008)

Names of family: Achyrocline satureioides (Lam.) DC.e Ageratum fastigiatum (Gardner) R.M. King & H. Rob. e
column3: For treating pain, used in the bath Flowers are viscous with a strong smell. Not grazed by cattle
Recent studies: Analgesic (Simões et al., 1988). Presence of volatile oil (Del-Vechio-Vieira et al., 2009a, 2009b; Gonçalves et al., 2011)

Names of family: Baccharis genistelloides subsp. crispa (Spreng,) Joch. Muell. (=B. trimera (Less.) DC., B. crispa Spreng. e,c,d,b
column3: Whole plant is extremely bitter, more bitter than quinine and Gentian, used to treat intermittent fevers

Data in fieldbook: Herva montana, Herva collegio no Rio, Fumo Bravo, Susualha/ Composée [A1-186; D-737]
column3: Often used for respiratory diseases

Data in fieldbook: Puejo da Praia, Carapixu, Composée, Melampodium [A1- 164; B2-2209bis
column3: It is bitter and used successfully as a febrifuge. Used for treatment of "gallico"

Names of family: Gymnanthemum amygdalinum (Delile) Sch. Bip. ex Walp. Vernonia condensata Baker)b
Data in fieldbook: Aça pece branco, Assa pece branco/Composée [B1-1598; B1- 1870ter
column3: Pleasant odour. The same use as salsaparrilha and caju do campo for venereal disease

Names of family: BIGNONIACEAE Handroanthus ochraceus (Cham.) Mattosecc Jacaranda caroba (Vell.) DC. e,c,d,b BIXACEAE
column3: Flowers are sudorific, similar to caroba Whole plant used to treat venereal diseases

Names of family: Cochlospermum regium (Mart. ex Schrank) Pilg. e.c.a.f CANNABACEAE
column3: Decoction of the roots is used against internal pains, from kicking and other accidents
Edible fruit said to be the size of a gooseberry
Edible yellow fruit the size of a lime, contains latex

Data in fieldbook: Malva do campo, folha santa, pinhão/Gutiferée [C1-455]
column3: Leaves are emollients and used in baths

Names of family: Combretum laxum Jacq. (=C. bugi Cambess)e.f COMMELINACEAE
column3: Very pleasant odour
Refreshing plant
